metadata.case_name: Managers of Teok Tea Estate and Dalim Tea Estate v. B. L. Sen, Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar and Labourers

facts.text: On March 11, 1952, Government of Assam issued notification No. GLR. 352/51/56 fixing minimum wages for employees in tea plantations in Assam, consisting of basic wages and dearness allowance, effective from March 30, 1952. For ordinary unskilled labour in Rest of Assam: Adult male (>16 years): Basic As.12/-, D.A. As.6/-, Total Rs.1/21 p.d.; Adult female: Basic As.11/-, D.A. As.5/-, Total Rs.1/4 p.d. Existing tasks and hours of work to continue until further orders.
By notification No. GLR. 44/51 dated April 16, 1952, Minimum Wages Rules introduced, Rule 24: Normal working day for adult: 9 hours, max 48 hours/week.
By notification No. GLR. 352/51 dated May 12, 1952, clarified that 'may' in March 11 notification means 'shall'; existing tasks and hours of work shall continue until further orders.

Prior to fixation, labourers in plucking tea leaves at Teok Tea Estate and Dalim Tea Estate paid basic wages: male As.8/- p.d. for 16 seers green leaves, female As.6/- p.d. for 12 seers; rate 6 ps. per seer. Extra (ticca) at 6 ps./seer for excess.
After fixation, managers continued payment at 6 ps./seer but refused extra unless exceeded 24 seers (male) / 22 seers (female), paying basic As.12/- and As.11/- only after that threshold.
Labourers contended existing task 16/12 seers entitled to basic As.12/-/As.11/- + extra 6 ps./seer beyond; difference As.4/- (male), As.5/- (female) p.d.
Labourers filed applications under S.20 Minimum Wages Act before Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar (first respondent) for directions to pay difference from March 30, 1952.
Managers contested: (1) applications not maintainable under S.20; (2) no fixed workload/task pre-fixation.

Deputy Commissioner entertained applications, recorded evidence, held: if applicants' version true, less than min wages paid, maintainable; found task 16/12 seers existed pre-fixation, basis for new basic wages; ordered payment of basic As.12/-/As.11/- for 16/12 seers + 6 ps./seer excess. Dated July 7, 1953.

Managers filed applications under Art.226 Constitution in Assam High Court (Civil Rules 147/148 of 1952) challenging Deputy Commissioner's orders; raised same contentions; dismissed; certificates under Art.133(1)(c) granted.
Appeals to Supreme Court with certificates.

legal_issues.text: Whether the March 11, 1952 notification fixed a minimum time rate irrespective of workload/task, or minimum wages related to existing task of 16/12 seers for basic wages.

Whether the labourers' claim for basic wages on existing task + extra for excess constitutes 'payment of less than the minimum rates of wages' under S.20 Minimum Wages Act, giving jurisdiction to Deputy Commissioner.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification fixed minimum time rate under S.3(2)(a); wages payable regardless of out-turn; no extra for excess over 16/12 seers; no fixed pre-existing task.
Always paid basic As.12/-/As.11/-; claim is for extra wages, not 'less than minimum rates'; no jurisdiction under S.20 as involves complicated facts/law, not plain reading.

respondent_arguments.text: Existing task 16/12 seers basis for basic wages pre-fixation at 6 ps./seer; notification increased basic to As.12/-/As.11/- for same task + extra at 6 ps./seer beyond; non-payment of extra until higher threshold = less than min wages.

court_reasoning.text: Both lower courts found pre-existing task 16/12 seers proved by evidence (Hazira Moharers); notification's 'existing tasks shall continue' relates basic wages to that task; not pure time rate as no need to mention tasks otherwise; intention to increase basic while keeping task same.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Basic wages fixed in relation to existing workload/task; extra payable at 6 ps./seer beyond.

court_reasoning.text: S.20 jurisdiction for 'less than minimum rates'; claim arguably for extra, but both lower courts concurred on merits in labourers' favour; proceedings under Art.226, certiorari discretionary; matters pending since 1952, no failure of justice to interfere.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decline to decide jurisdiction; merits correctly found for respondents; dismiss appeals.

holdings.text: Notification fixed minimum wages related to existing task of 16 seers (male)/12 seers (female) for basic As.12/-/As.11/- + extra 6 ps./seer beyond.
No interference with lower orders upholding labourers' claims despite potential jurisdiction issue under S.20.

precedents_cited.relevance: Proceedings by way of certiorari are discretionary; High Court could refuse writs if no failure of justice.

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act, 1948 (Act XI of 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Fixation of minimum wages (time/piece/guaranteed rates); claims for less than minimum wages; authority to hear and direct payment.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to SC; writ jurisdiction of High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding the Deputy Commissioner's orders and High Court's dismissal of Art.226 petitions; confirmed labourers entitled to basic wages of As.12/- per day for males (16 seers) and As.11/- for females (12 seers) plus extra at 6 ps. per seer beyond, as both lower forums correctly found on merits despite potential S.20 jurisdiction issue.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellants; status quo upheld for labourers' claims.

key_quotes.text: "The direction that the existing workload or task was to continue until further orders on the contrary goes to show that the basic wages mentioned in the Schedule were related to the existing workload or task"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning linking notification to pre-existing task.

key_quotes.text: "We do not propose to decide this question of jurisdiction as in the instant cases we have... the adjudication of the main disputes between the parties by the High Court itself."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court avoids jurisdiction ruling, affirms on merits.

key_quotes.text: "Proceedings by way of certiorari are not of course."
key_quotes.speaker: court
